Staff said to check the following day which I did only to be told again that they still do not have vacant rooms, this was at 130p just 30mins shy of actual check-in time. Missed the first day of my conference because I had to look for hotels that had a vacancy for 5 days. The hotel made no efforts in helping with locating other hotels. HORRIBLE, HORRIBLE, HORRIBLE!!!

Reviews.Title: “Pleasant staff”
Reviews.Author: random_tangent
Reviews.Content: I stay at the Town and Country each year for a professional conference (Plant and Animal Genome). With the exception of the conference center, the facilities are a bit dated. On the other hand, my experience with the staff is always pleasant. In particular, at the Trellis restaurant, the staff remembers folks who come by only once a year. In particular, Pati Muklevicz is quite friendly and provides fine service.

Reviews.Title: “A great and relaxing stay - as always”
Reviews.Author: jeffke999
Reviews.Content: Just finishd up a greaty conference and stay at the hotel. Each year is is enjoyable and the service provided at the Trellis by Angelica Stephens is worth the visit alone. My kids look forward th the trip each year and always look forward to the stay, the weather, th hotel and the wonderful friendly breakfasts with Angelica at the Trellis by the pool. Can't wait for next year!! Not looking forward to returning to -20 weather back home ;-(

Reviews.Title: “Always a pleasure”
Reviews.Author: enophile28
Reviews.Content: I have had the opportunity to stay for a week in January every year at the Town and Country for the last 10 years (the Plant and Animal Genome Meeting). The grounds are absolutely beautiful! Rooms are comfortable and the hotel staff are very warm and friendly. I must especially commend the staff at Trellis' restaurant. My friend and I have an annual 'brunch' on the patio and have had the pleasure of getting to know the staff over the years. Angelica Stephens and Pati Muklevic, always have a welcoming smile and treat us like family. Jacinto Baez makes the best Bloody Mary in town. The light rail station at the T&C makes traveling in town extremely convenient. I know I'll be back next year and am already looking forward to it. Thanks T&C!

Reviews.Title: “Great service”
Reviews.Author: cgb2191
Reviews.Content: We recently attended a professional convention held at the Town & Country Resort & Convention Center and were delighted to find the facilities tailor-made for the conference and for guest comfort. Our room in the tower was spotless and nicely-appointed (sumptuous Egyptian cotton sheets, too); the grounds were immaculate and abounding in gorgeous rose gardens. Everywhere--from the parking lot attendants to desk staff to restaurant workers--we were greeted and helped by genuinely friendly folks. I especially commend Pati Muklevicz at Trellises Restaurant, who waited on us for breakfast at our first visit, and again at lunch, when we decided to return to enjoy more of the great food and wonderful hospitality

Reviews.Title: “Individual Staff Members were Great”
Reviews.Author: Counseler1
Reviews.Content: This stay was part of a large, (several hundred attendees) meeting and convention of a large multi-national professional society. On check in we found the Front Desk staff to be just routine and not particularly helpful or creative. We arrived at approx. 2PM and although the hotel was not close to full, we were made to wait until the "official" check in time of 4PM - then shown to a sub standard room adjacent to the nearby freeway. Obviously very noisy. We suffered through the first night and in the AM went to the Trellises Restaurant on the property for breakfast and found a completely different environment than we had experienced at the Front Desk. The Restaurant Manager, Robin Davis listened to our complaints, then while we were eating called Trish Williams of the Reservations Dept, and relocated us to a superior, and quiet, room quickly and efficiently. This changed our experience from negative to positive and allowed us to concentrate on the seminar and meeting subjects rather than the adjacent noisy traffic. Thanks again ti Robin and Trish.

Reviews.Title: “Just O.K.”
Reviews.Author: jarbra15
Reviews.Content: This is one huge hotel. You need a map just to find your way around. I stayed in one of the older motel quality rooms which was extremely small and across from a conference center. The beds were comfortable, the TV was horrible. The decor was really old fashioned. The hotel staff could give a darn if you are sleeping at 5:30 in the morning as they are banging stuff around, whistling ect. This happened every morning. There is no complimentary breakfast but there are restaurants on the premises. The price is high for what you get. You pay for parking and internet which makes the price of a room considerably more. The location is convienient especially to the San Diego Transit system a definite plus.

Reviews.Title: “Best Holiday Party Ever”
Reviews.Author: sdepascl
Reviews.Content: My husband's company holiday party was held at the Town and Country hotel this past Saturday evening in Trellises and it was the best party ever, from the room, decor, bar service, entertainment, delicious food and friendly staff - everything was perfect!! Our server Pati was always there when we needed her and Robin Davis & Chef Patrick saw to it that everyone had an unsurpassed holiday event. Everyone left talking about the details of an exceptional evening!

Reviews.Title: “Gem of San Diego”
Reviews.Author: flattop1950
Reviews.Content: The Town and Country Resort .was the Auto Clubs choice to stay for a romantic night. I wish we would have stayed longer.. We were in a delightful cottage atmosphere room 3506 surrounded by a beautiful garden of flowers and fountains by the pool. We had checked in at 2:30 and had some trouble with the front desk staff. The were unconcerned and rude. They told us our room number and told us to go wait in our car for 30 minutes, at that time my husband took our luggage to the bench outside our room to find out that someone else was in that room. I asked a maid to check the front desk for me and she returned and told me they said I needed to walk all the way over there to ask them what my room number was and they were aware I was on oxygen. We finally got in our room at 3:30 which is unexceptable to me. I felt as though they were not going to let us in 1 minute before 3pm, which was check in time which also propted me to me sure and exit by 11am as to not stir them up. So it was rush, rush rush. After that we had made a dinner choice and our choice was this restaurant a few feet from our room. Trellises on the property and it was wonderful. the food was the best ever and we just returned from a cruise ship, but most of all was the service. Our server Don Andrew made outr stay a positive one after the check in experience.. He is a Gem at the restaurant, with his wonderful personality, wit and attentive call to details. He made out dining experience so great, I can't wait to return to the San Diego.. Town & Country resort you made a very good choice when you employeed Don Andrew and having the best food in town. And by the way the Christmas decor was delightful and got us in the spirit of Christmas.

Reviews.Title: “Had a great time.”
Reviews.Author: DIJNiwot
Reviews.Content: Our little bungalow by the pool was very quaint. We had a lovely view of the garden as well. Walking to the Trellis restaurant took less than a minute. We ate there frequently and enjoyed every meal. The wonderful service we received from Don, Patti and Robin made our trip that much more enjoyable. Don, you're a nut.....thanks for the special attention and superb service. Our rooms were clean and made up in a very timely manner. Check-in desk, concierge, information desk, all very friendly and more than eager to help. Very nice. We also enjoyed the convenience of having such a nice mall within walking distance of the hotel. We didn't use the tram or the train but might do so on our next visit which I hope will be soon.

Reviews.Title: “Bedbug Alert!!!”
Reviews.Author: Costazul
Reviews.Content: Stayed at a computer conference week of Nov 8th in the big tower in room 1319. Received bites on legs and arms during my whole stay. I thought I was allergic to a detergent or something but it was a row of bites. Years ago I had an encounter with bedbugs so I know how it looks like. Informed the front desk but they weren't to receptive. Nice clean hotel in good location but unfortunately it turned out to be a very unpleasant experience due to the infestation :(

Reviews.Title: “Delightful Service”
Reviews.Author: VictorEmanual
Reviews.Content: JesusCentral.com staff and affiliates would like to sincerely thank, Ms. Angelica Stephens for delightful services rendered during our stay at the Town & Country Resort. Our stay in room 3518 was all that we expected and beyond. Ms. Stephens conducted her self in an extremely professional manner and we would like to recommend her services to any and all who stay at the Town & Country Resort. Thank you.

Reviews.Title: “Pleasant Surprise”
Reviews.Author: NYdweller7
Reviews.Content: A friend of mine, Pati Muklevicz referred me to this fine establishment and she did not let me down. The service was great and the food was wonderful. This experience made my CA stay a whole lot nicer.

Reviews.Title: “Trellis restaurant”
Reviews.Author: ozarkVirginia
Reviews.Content: During our visit to San Diego we stayed at the Town and Country Resort Hotel . We had a room in the garden bunglalow area near the Trellis Restaurant. We ate many of our meals there and were throughly impressed with the menu, service, atmosphere and friendlliness of the staff. There was no other restaurant in the city that we liked better, not even The Prado at Balboa Park. Robin Davis, who manages the restaurant, made our meals there extremely enjoyable. All of our US Navy reunion group, who were staying at the hotel, concurred.

Reviews.Title: “Average room in an oversized, sprawling complex”
Reviews.Author: TravelingManSpokane
Reviews.Content: The Town and Country Resort hotel is a sprawling mess of a hotel complex. There are modern towers and quaint bungalows spread out across the vast acreage. There are also some extremely average old, apartment-style rooms sprinkled into the mix. Unfortunately, I got one of those rooms in October 2008. For the privilege of staying in room #3714, I paid $169 for a Saturday night and $189 for a Sunday night. One earlier reviewer said this was "Motel rooms at hotel prices" and I think that nails it on the head. The hotel complex is so huge that you need a printed map to figure out where you are and where you're going and there are also maps with the familiar "you are here" arrow spread out over the grounds. My room was quite difficult to find, due mainly to the fact that the well-meaning but clueless young woman on the front desk who checked me in told me the room was on the first floor when it was indeed on the SECOND FLOOR instead. Whoops! Strike one. The room, once I found it, was very average. The bedroom and bathroom felt small and cramped. The bed was very comfortable, though although the bedspread and room decorations were old and tired. It had an old, small TV and the balcony looked out to the back side of one of the many meeting and convention facilities on the "Resort" property. I put "Resort" in quotes because, even though there are a few nice areas of the hotel complex, I felt that the room I got stuck with dispelled the notion that I was at a resort. The "view" was a joke, unless you like looking at the back side of another building ten feet away. I heard a great deal of noise from the rooms next door and below me, and even more noise from the hotel's maintenance, landscaping and housekeeping staffs wheeling their carts right outside. I had stayed at this hotel several years ago and stayed in one of the Towers, which made a great deal of difference. I enjoyed that stay a lot more than I enjoyed this one. This is not to say my stay this year was a total loss. The T&C is quite close to the Trolley line that runs east-west and is quite convenient to travel around San Diego. There's a mediocre but serviceable golf course next door and a great deal of shopping available in Mission Valley. The T&C property does have a couple of pools, but some of them are much nicer than others. The one near the lobby and one of the resort's restaurants is decent, but the one outside one of the towers is quite noisy, and there's another small pool in the courtyard of one series of rooms that reminded me of a Motel 6. Not all was average here: I enjoyed two wonderful breakfasts sitting in the San Diego sunshine outside the Trellises restaurant. If I ever stay here again, I'll have a better idea which area of the property I'd aim for and which is to be avoided.

Reviews.Title: “Resort Hotel with 2 star quality....”
Reviews.Author: MyLucretia
Reviews.Content: Stayed at the Town & Country and all I can say is never again will I stay at Town & Country. The beds were EXTREMELY uncomfortable & hard, the maid service was not up to par (only supply towels but never really cleans the room-just dumps the trash can) , the restaurants were so overpriced & not affordable when you have children, and finally the internet is soooo overpriced..(my spouse & I had both our laptops and we were charged twice) Sorry Town & Country but your lovely flower gardens do make up for lack of up keep and quality.

Reviews.Title: “The room decor will certainly please the Victorian and flowered bedspread crowd”
Reviews.Author: travel47Seattle
Reviews.Content: The T&C is a mixed bag. I stayed there two nights for a company related function. Our organization used the meeting facilities. Overall, the rooms, restaurants and most facilities seem older and dated. The room decor will certainly please the Victorian and flowered bedspread crowd.... think of your grandmother. While my room was clean, a coworker complained to the office of black mold in the tub. It was cleaned. The banquet facilities are dated with the room lighting being only acceptable. The meeting staff was helpful and the catered lunches met our expectations. We had several questions and requests and the meeting and catering staff were responsive. Our company presentation for 80 one day and 200 the next went well. The restaurants were a mixed bag. The brunch at the cafe was $14 and below par for a Marriott Courtyard. The Steak House on this large property was a bit pricy and dowdy in appearance. One coworker liked her prime rib very much while other entrees were okay. The wait staff was helpful and accommodating. The health club was up to date and new. It only lacked an elliptical trainer. Unfortunately, admission was $8 even for registered guests. A mixed bag...

Reviews.Title: “We were happy there”
Reviews.Author: kuchenesser
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed at the T/C for five days for a Navy Ship reunion, our room was in the Regency Tower. After reading earlier reviews, I was almost fearful when we drove in, had no trouble parking. Clerk in the Lobby was pleasant, check in took only a few minutes. Our room was nice, a bit old fashioned, but clean, nice bathroom, we opened the windows the whole time we were there for nice fresh breezy air. We needed a refrigerator for my husband's insulin, and they brought one up in 20 minutes and we were not charged anything for it either. Service at the Trellises was always good, food was excellent, we never did the buffet however, always ordered from the menu. Swimming pools were clean, lots of clean towels each day. The proximity to that nice shopping Mall is great, and the trolley too, as long as a person can walk ok. Location is good. We did have that "Blue Girl" painting in there, I had forgotten someone on here mentioning it until some of the others from our reunion group spoke of it, some even covered the painting up with a towel, couldn't stand it. They said it was in the halls too, but I didn't see it in our hall. I don't know what it is with that painting that freaks people out though. Sort of funny in a way.

Reviews.Title: “Town and country resort great.”
Reviews.Author: ejm0808
Reviews.Content: We spent 3 days at this great location. 40 acres of grounds, 4 restaurtants, including one fine dining that was quite reasonable. A short walk to the cable car tram which can take you downtown in 10 minutes. Golf course attached. Room was priced right and very Large, right off the beautiful pool. I believe it was a calif king bed, four poster. Great. TV could be larger than 19 inch. We expected noise from the pool but it was little used and a great place to sit for coffee or cocktails. The grounds, especially the Roses were spectacular. The Trellis restaurant , and especially their manager Robin was the nicest feature. Great meal and service for our group, and correctly priced as well. Excellent menu, you could not do better really. Fresh, on property baked goods were really great. conf no. was 18880415.

Reviews.Title: “Shabby, FAR past its prime, a lot of money for what you get”
Reviews.Author: Traveler345_8
Reviews.Content: I was at this hotel for a conference, and was very disappointed in the property. It's a huge facility, very poorly maintained and seriously overpriced. I only ate there for one meal, and it was barely edible. And they even charge for parking! A rip off. My room was in the high rise, and each night they had parties by the pool below, with loud music. The remote control from the TV had a dying battery, and there was a drippy faucet, and the upholstery was OLD. It was once a very nice place but poor maintenance is apparent everywhere you look. The whole place is planted with thousands of rose bushes, but the flowers were all wilting and drooping. If they are going to try to do a 'Disneyland' type of decor, they need to put a whole lot more effort into maintenance. There was junk all over the place... Stay someplace else.

Reviews.Title: “Don't be dissuaded... NICE!”
Reviews.Author: Rambler989
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the T&C for a conference in September '08 and was a little worried based on previous reviews. Don't worry--I had a great stay!! Although the property is a little old (I described it to friends as the resort in Dirty Dancing but I couldn't find the cool party to bring my watermelon to) but it is totally clean. I checked the usual places for bed bugs and the place came up clean. The restaurants were also really good (Kelly's was the best for steaks) The housekeeping staff was prompt and good. My only complaints are the (and they are minimal) following: -Cable was crappy (very few channels) -Drinks were VERY expensive - Comforters and top blankets were gross

Reviews.Title: “Motel rooms at hotel prices”
Reviews.Author: sB_Loves2Travel
Reviews.Content: Well, I read the reviews before I made my reservation but due to a special circumstance (long story!) I decided to stay here anyway. I've stayed at motels that are nicer than this hotel. I would not recommend nor go back there again. I paid $179 a night and definitely not worth it by my measures.

Reviews.Title: “A place to avoid, especially on business”
Reviews.Author: javelin98
Reviews.Content: I recently stayed at the Town and Country Hotel for a conference, and I absolutely will never willingly set foot here again; in fact, I'm also recommending to my employer that we never schedule another seminar there. I hadn't read any reviews whatsoever about the place before heading there, so I didn't have any preconceived notions about what I would find, other than the pictures on the hotel's website. Needless to say, the hotel is completely unacceptable as a business destination. So, where to begin... * Accommodations The room we stayed in was in one of the hotel's two towers, known as the Regency. The hotel was decrepit. Everywhere you look, paint is scraped and chipped, lightbulbs are burnt out (and allowed to stay that way), windows have dirt in the corners, there are dings in the walls and door jambs, and other such problems. Our room itself has obviously not been updated since the late 80's, to include the comforter, which was faded and frayed. The bathroom is lit by two dim bulbs, which is fine, since brighter light would have drawn even more attention to the stained bathtub, yellowed and peeling grout, and rusty hinges on the door. The door itself looks like it has been repeatedly urinated on, as it is streaked yellow. The air conditioning in our room was so pitiful that we ran it non-stop from the time we arrived to the time we left, and it was never able to bring the room temp below 72º. It was also unable to remove the mugginess from the air. We slept with the window open the first night, but, sad to say, our room faced the San Diego Herald-Tribune loading docks, so at 3:30 AM we were assailed with the crash of tractor-trailers backing up to receive shipments of newspapers. The window stayed closed after that. The grounds were beautiful, with rose bushes everywhere, and arbors, trellises, and cute little architectural touches in abundance. Of course, many of those touches, such as ornamental scrollwork, were straight from Home Depot and simply glued in place and painted; they were often askew or chipped and peeling. It was the equivalent of adding as much garnish to a dinner plate as possible to try and hide the fact that the main course was only so much boiled shoe-leather. In addition to everything else, our toilet stopped flushing on the second day. After we called maintenance to fix it, it wouldn't stop flushing. It's feast or famine at the Town & Country. Speaking of famine... * Food Business travelers and convention-goers are usually on a time crunch, as they have only so much time to eat and then be back at the next session or class. The food service at the hotel was so slow that a number of us had to skip meals or eat cold cuts from the deli; when you have only an hour and it takes 40 minutes to get just your drinks, there is a problem. The food was also sub-par; the breakfast buffet at the Terrace Cafe is to be avoided at all costs. The food is cold, rubbery, and of a quality well below that of most fast-food places. The ribs at Kelly's Steakhouse were overdone and dried out, as was the BBQ chicken; the only thing worth eating was the appetizer. Charlie's Bar & Grill was agonizingly slow and overpriced; $13 hamburgers and expensive sodas can quickly eat up your per-diem allowance. * Connectivity As a business traveler, it is essential to stay connected to the office, and Internet access is a key part of that for anyone operating in the 21st century. Here, too, the Town and Country was a let-down. With no wired access, you are forced to purchase ($3 an hour or $10 for 24 hours) wi-fi access through a vendor called LodgeNet. However, the access was so spotty that I was unable to reliably check email, and had to spend over ninety minutes on the phone with LodgeNet tech support to even get connected. * Staff The front-office staff were professional to the point of being brusque, but I only had to deal with them rarely. The waitstaff at Kelly's were utterly clueless, even to the point of failing to unlock the front door on time (we had to go in through the lounge and then tell them that the door was still locked). The waitstaff at Charlie's were arrogant and ignorant of the needs of the customers. The only two places I found excellent staff were at the Trellises restaurant and the in the housekeeping staff. At Trellises, both Angelica and Jesus, and a third gentleman whose name I didn't catch, were charming and responsive, and the food was excellent. As for the housekeeping staff, they did an excellent job with what they had to work with, and our housekeeper took extra special care with my boys' stuffed animals and even hung our wet swimsuits back up after having cleaned the bathroom. * Conclusions Overall, the front-line staff are doing the best they can in the absence of involved and commited top management, which may either be uninterested or incapable of improving the place. The Town and Country has the feeling of a sinking cruise liner; the band is still playing, but the ship is getting lower and lower in the water, and it is only a matter of time before it slips beneath the waves. Unless it is saved by a rescuer with an infusion of cash and competence, the Town and Country does not have much longer to live. I have already sent a note to our central education office (of a government agency with 160,000 employees) asking them to avoid scheduling us at this hotel in the future.

Reviews.Title: “Average Stay”
Reviews.Author: noslengnow
Reviews.Content: Stayed here as part of the San Diego Comic Con room block. A pretty standard hotel stay. Nothing major to complain about. Check-in took about 10 minutes. Parked in the rear lot, which was closer to where our room was. Parking fee was normal (we're from San Francisco Bay Area so we're used to paying for parking rather than expecting it to be free). Hotel room was small and very dated decor (country style) but for us it was just a place to sleep and rest so we didn't much mind the decor. Common walls between rooms are very thin though and if you have neighbors it can definitely be an issue. The location is convenient to the San Diego Trolley and buses plus a mall as well. We took advantage of the trolley location to get to Downtown San Diego and it was pretty convenient. Checkout as a bit weird though. We attempted to checkout via the television system and it told us that we couldn't check out through that until 11:10 a.m., which is 10 minutes beyond the actual check out time. We ended up driving back up to the lobby and checking out there. The line was 5 or 6 people deep so it took about 15 minutes. All told, driving back to the front and waiting in line probably used up 20 to 25 minutes that we could saved had the television checkout been working properly. Overall minor quibbles though. The convenient location for us definitely was a plus in an otherwise average hotel stay.

Reviews.Title: “Don't waste your time here--go elsewhere on Hotel Circle”
Reviews.Author: CincinnatiTrav_l_r
Reviews.Content: Stayed here with a previous conference a few years back--even staying on the company's dime, I would absolutely not recommend this "resort" (?). See reasons below: Check-in debacle: Checked in at 10 p.m. with two young children to find out that they didn't have "a room with a bed" available for us until the following day. Yes, folks, there are indeed hotel rooms without beds?!?!? Not to mention that the room had been reserved for nearly two months, so what happened to our room? Okay, whatever...the kids and I are tired from being in planes and airports for the past 6 hours. Have to wait for the only bellhop in the place (yes, only one on a busy Saturday night and the place was hopping). He takes a large group off to their room--we can't walk to ours w/ our bags and a brass luggage cart because the staff "can't allow guests to use them" (oddly enough, they stay chained up to posts around the property). So we wait, and wait...and wait some more. The 6 minutes slowly turned into 25 minutes :( Ugh...tired, grumpy kids... Make it to the bed-less hotel room (via golf cart because it's all of a 2-minute ride and all) and they have a portable cot/bed delivered. There is a pullout sofa bed in the room, but it's so paper thin and uncomfortable that we are forced to actually rearrange heavy furniture in this room so that my youngest can sleep on two overstuffed chairs that are facing each other. Sigh... Paid $35 for two kids' buffets and 1 adult buffet for breakfast the next morning since we were all starving from our travels. The food was below par, although the service was great. I found this to be true throughout the stay. The maids and waitstaff were courteous and friendly, while the "professional" staff up front could learn some customer service lessons from these hardworking folks! Honestly!!!! To add insult to injury, I make it over to the supposed state-of-the-art workout facility (I can't vouch for this because I didn't actually go into it OR see anyone using it at any point in passing by) on the grounds inside of the day spa (also, not busy) to be greeted by the less-than-enthusiastic desk person by, "Oh, are you staying here with a conference?" I reply with, "Well, yes I am." Then: "Oh, they must have forgotten to tell you about the fee for use: $8/day." WHAT??? I'm paying $14 per day to park, ungodly markup on ho-hum food, overpriced (not to mention old and run-down furnishings in the) room, and now I'm nickle-and-dimed to workout??? I immediately left, of course, only to watch another fellow walk in and right back out. Who pays to use a treadmill at a hotel? I'm sure the Vagabond Inn around the corner has a free workout facility. In the end, I'm sure the management will kindly thank me for my feedback and apologetically promise to look into the issues I raised (as you've probably read in the other 150+ previous reviews). But, it's obvious to anyone and everyone reading these that the management is NOT willing to follow through with this because the same complaints would not be consistently arising. Okay, management, let's here a real game plan on turning this place around?!?!?! All in all, save your money and stay somewhere else on Hotel Circle. Everything in this area is convenient and accessible, not just the Town & Country. Believe me...I gave it a second chance and will NOT make it a third!

Reviews.Title: “No "Aloha" spirit here”
Reviews.Author: Big_Kuhuna
Reviews.Content: My son and I just returned from our trip to San Diego CA. The reason for the trip was to visit San Diego State University which he will be attending next year as a freshman. We stayed at Town and Country Resort Hotel for 3 days recommended by the AAA, and here's my review; 1) Checking-in to the Town and Country hotel was a nightmare! There were no/limited temporary parking spaces for hotel guests. The only parking lot that was available was blocked in and was for the paying customers only. Just as other hotel guests trying to find someplace to park their car, we were driving around and around in circles looking for open spots anywhere on the side of the building since there were no parking on the street. We ended up parking on the the driveway for hotel delivery truck. Many of the cars were double parked and drivers were fighting over an illegal parking space. It was a total pandemonium with and cars traveling in both directions on this narrow corridor in front of the entrance with either driver wanting to budge. 2) As expected there were long lines with people waiting to check-in (That resembles airport check-in) with lines curved around several times in front of lobby. The line was moving very slow due to only half of the front counter were open/manned and some of the guests were frustrated and cranky. After the mayhem outside the hotel fighting over a parking spot who could blame them. After about 20 minutes of waiting it was my turn. When I heard "Next in line" I stepped up to the counter. The customer service person behind the desk must be having a bad day by the way she moved about the behind the counter and from the way she handled my paperwork. When I mentioned to her about the parking situation/experience, she seemed unsympathetic. 3) After first night of stay, a maid left a (One liter bottle of water) in our room that says $2.50 if the seal is broken. This is not a complimentary bottle of water mind you. Anyway, I wasn't dying of thirst so we left that bottle of water alone. Later on that evening we ordered an In-room dining service; two small plate of something called California fruit palette and (Although there were no bottle water listed on their menu) 4 bottles of water. After the food delivery guy who banged on our front door continuously until we opened the door, as if we didn't hear after the first bang, we received our tray of food. The total bill came to whopping $70.00 dollars!! When I read the itemized receipt, to my surprise $5.00 per 20 oz bottle water X 4 = $20.00! I should've just opened the one liter bottle of water that was sitting on the desk for just $2.50. I don't get it. When I asked the person working at the front desk how do you justify charging $5.00 for 20 0z bottle of water from the kitchen and then you leave one liter bottle in the room for $2.50? He had a very puzzled look on his face but gave me no answer. 4) If you like bugs there were plenty of that in our room. Our room guest consist of: one "Earwig" bug in our sink to greet us and two pretty good size spiders crawling around our ceiling doing tricks. Bugs don't bother us, however, something to watch for in your room if you have family members who are afraid of the bugs. 5) I've traveled all over the United States and stayed in many of the major hotel chains, and Town and Country hotel is our first that we have stayed that charges parking fee. When our son attends San Diego State University next year to play football we will be visiting San Diego often, however, Town and Country will NOT be on our list of hotel we would want to stay. Overall, Town and Country experience is at the bottom.

Reviews.Title: “Met my expectations”
Reviews.Author: mclanea
Reviews.Content: I recently stayed at the Town & Country for 8 days on business with my family. After reading lots of reviews I was prepared for the worst. In actuality, it isn't a horrible place to stay. - The rooms are adequate and clean. Notice I didn't say "spacious" as they are quite small if you have a family with you. (We had 2 adults, 2 kids) If you were by yourself the room would be large enough. There are no amenities in the rooms. No fridge! You are getting beds, a TV, a dresser, and a bathroom. That's it. - The property. It is well maintained. The biggest issue is that the layout is horrid. We were there for 8 days and got lost on the way to check out! It wasn't just me... we spent a lot of time trying to help people who were lost. - Our rate included breakfast at the buffet. If you ate it one day it would be great. But after 7 of them we were tired of the same breakfast every morning. Also, some days the kids were free and other times were charged. Likewise, the buffet wasn't included in the cost of our rate as we were charged tax on it! (Not like at typical places that include breakfast bars, really odd.) - Parking, $8/day adds up. You don't pay for parking at other nearby hotels. - Service staff. They were really professional. In fact, TOO professional for me. We at the same place every morning for 7 days. Each morning they pretended like they hadn't seen us before. I mean seriously... I stop at Starbucks more than 2 days in a row and they remember me. What's up with that? - The creepy painting in nearly every room is world famous. They can't get rid of it now. http://kristenmclane.com/2008/07/23/wordless-wednesday-creepy-girl/ All of that said, we had a decent time. If you forget about the word "resort" and just treat the hotel like camp... you'll like it. Our kids loved that it had a few pools to chose from. It was conveniently located. And the price was very reasonable.

Reviews.Title: “Exceeded expectations!”
Reviews.Author: jcj34
Reviews.Content: Having booked on Priceline we were disappointed to read the negative reviews on Town and Country. Needless to say, we arrived with low expectations. After a seamless and courteous check-in we were directed to our room and, although a bit outdated, the room was clean and in a great location. I'm incredibily surprised to read reviews that this isn't necessarily a family friendly property. To the contrary, it was perfect. The day we arrived we found out that they were playing Ratattouille on their garden lawn that evening complete with free popcorn and dollar snacks ... what a perfect way to begin our vacation. Thanks Town and Country for exceeding our expectations.

Reviews.Title: “Bait & Switch Rates”
Reviews.Author: smtravelor
Reviews.Content: Booked room in Feb 2008 for a business conference in May 2008 and received the confimation. When I checked out they told me that my billing was "routed" to someone else for billing. I requested an invoice and it was blank. They could not tell who the bill went to. Two weeks later it was posted to my VISA bill, but at a higher rate than it was booked for. I contacted Town and Country and was told they had a rate increase between when I booked the room and stayed so I have to pay the higher rate. I am currently disputing the extra charges with my VISA company and filed a complaint with BBB. Outdated and not very clean. I would not recommend this place to anyone.

Reviews.Title: “Check-in Experience paints the picture”
Reviews.Author: cruiseauthor
Reviews.Content: After arriving at the hotel close to midnight, I was informed that I couldn't check in because the computers were down. There were a few others in the lobby fuming because they couldn't check in either. We were all there to attend a travel industry conference at the hotel - what a terrible first impression! We were offered nothing, and when I asked for water so I could take some medication, I was informed where the soda machine was! The rest of the stay was equally disappointing - this entire resort needs a huge overhaul.

Reviews.Title: “A great time at the Town and Country!”
Reviews.Author: Brittanicus
Reviews.Content: In May 2008, the Mariner/Marlin Association, an affinity group of pilots and aircrews who once flew in U.S. Navy seaplanes such as the Martin PBM and the Martin Marlin, held its annual convention at the Town & Country Resort in San Diego. Though I was familiar with San Diego, I was unaware of the resort located at 500 Hotel Circle in San Diego, CA. Over the years, I have traveled to many parts of the world, especially Europe and the Far East but I have never once found an establishment with such a uniformly well-trained and friendly staff. Never do you have the feeling that anyone is doing you a favor in responding to your concerns. This was amazing to me in a staff that runs close to 1500 people. In addition, the resort is the most beatifully landscaped that I have ever visited and the myriad of plants is meticulously maintained by an army of gardeners. The resort has numerous convention facilities and several excellent restaurants but is also a good place for a simple getaway. Since it is not new, having been in existence since 1953, it might not appeal to the 'Belaggio' set but renovation and addition of new buildings goes on annually and the existing buildings are well maintained. Everyone at the convention loved the place! Highly recommended.

Reviews.Title: “Awful and old..”
Reviews.Author: SanDiegoSkyler
Reviews.Content: I have stayed there several times over the years. There is constant construction and the rooms are outdated. Plus there are hidden fees even in the restaurants that is not included in room prices. I ran into the owner while staying with family and they treated us very rude. I will never stay there again!

Reviews.Title: “More than what people expect”
Reviews.Author: skynsidhawaii
Reviews.Content: Like everyone else, I was here for a conference since it is right next to the conference center. The first night I got there, they stated that we would be put in to a suite with a couch bed (translation: semisuite) and that we would have to leave the room the next day and move into a regular room. Although the room was really nice and had an outside patio that goes to the pool, the inconvenience of having to check out and check in did not set well with me, especially when I had a seminar in the morning that I needed to attend to. However, they did take some responsibility and redeemed themselves by offering me and my wife a password for free internet use access (which is $10.00 per day value) and since I just bought a macbook the day before, my wife was happy with that. Mind you, other than the check in process, the hotel is a very nice place to stay. They take good care of their area and their gardens and the paths/walkways were gorgeous with a splendid assortment of roses, plants, and fountains fixated all over the place which would make any high school prom want to book this place. It is, funny to say, a labyrinth of twists and turns (and actually a dead end in one area between the pool/check in lobby) which makes you feel like you are in Frances Hodgson Burnett's "The Secret Garden" rather than a hotel resort. Also, as you and as you cross though the bridge to the behind the hotel to go through the Fashion Valley Mall (a superb outdoor mall!), you have to cross the small San Diego river. People just pass by it to go to the mall, but it is a really nice area with ducks waddling around and squirrels going to and fro the area as a more natural California scene from balboa park (which is driving distance to the area). For the two rooms that I stayed, they were really nice. The suite was furnished with a basic kitchenette of a microwave and an empty compact refrigerator which was wasn’t stocked with drinks where the hotel would charge you up the ying yang for (although they offer a litter of aquafina for a $2.50 convenience charge). The décor of the area was really nice with vases and plants and an outside patio to the pool. The second room that I stayed in was a regular one bedroom king size room equipped with the standard amenities. The inside room had a lovely blue theme and bed was comfortable with a nice view being on the third floor. Now, if you have the money for the high rollers, if you get a presidential suite on the tenth floor like my boss had, you will be sitting in first class with Donald Trump. Equipped with a nice indoor bar, ample space to throw an executive party and a gorgeous view of the resort, seeing this room was definitely one of the highlights of my trip. They even have a little potted tree bush the size of a tiny christmas on the left and right side of the doorway before you enter the room, now that's class! The staff was very competent in what they do and was very friendly and accommodating in whatever I needed. My family sent me a special package, and the people in the front desk were very helpful in assisting me to get my package safely and securely. It was funny because when I left the last day, the guy that helped in for the bell hop area next to the front desk remembered me and waived good bye to me, and that is the personalized service that I enjoy. All in all, the Town and Country is a wonderful place to stay. I think that they can get overbooked due to the proximity of being next to the conference center, but otherwise, it was really good experience for me and would recommend it to my friend, especially if they can afford the presidential suites. They would definitely get their moneys worth!

Reviews.Title: “Bit like 'The Prisoner' village”
Reviews.Author: New_month_New_city
Reviews.Content: Yet another conference meant that I stayed at this hotel. As these things go it wasn't bad. I was in one of the motel style low-rise blocks on the 2nd floor. Room was nice enough, and certainly large, however windows didn't close properly letting in road noise. Decor was also slightly peculiar and I banged my head on the low rise chandelier a couple of times. Not much light (natural or otherwise) meant that it was difficult to work in the room and wifi connection was a little intermittent. The site itself is strange. I like to think I have a reasonable sense of direction, so didn't get too lost. There were a couple of points where I ended up walking down a road only to find I couldn't get through to where I was aiming though. Staff were all very helpful and well turned out, rooms seemed clean, though I did find a previous occupant's sweet wrapper under the corner of the TV cabinet. Overall it's far from the worst place that I've stayed, but hardly stood out as a fantastic hotel. A resounding 'meh'.

Reviews.Title: “excellent value and location”
Reviews.Author: traveltwentyfour
Reviews.Content: We were staying in the general vicinity and unhappy with our hotel and noticed Town and Country and thought it would be out of our price range. The grounds and pool area looked lovely and the front desk area was also very appealing. Happily, we got an excellent travel industry rate and a very nice room in the tower location on a higher floor towards the ends of the building where the end units angled inward giving us a quieter room. We thought the room had generouse space and looked newly decorated with tasteful funishings. The beds were very comfortable. My room-mate is very picky on cleanliness and suffers from asthma and reacts to any odours and she could not find fault with anything. The location is excellent to the trolley and fashion mall. We could not hesitate to recommend this hotel based on our experience.

Reviews.Title: “Could be worse, could be better”
Reviews.Author: kjnielsen206
Reviews.Content: I was here for a conference like everyone else, plus I stayed for two extra nights for sightseeing etc. The decor of the room is like going to Grandma's house without the smell of Ben-Gay and Vaseline Bath Beads. The layout is very confusing, the maps not to scale and the lanes are unmarked. The food via room service is rather poor and the food you buy at the little on-site shops and cafes is outrageously priced. The parking fee is outrageous. I used the overnight dry cleaning service, my items arrived an hour before my banquet-scary. I asked for a late check out, if you stay 2 hours past, you are changed for a half day, 4 hours-you are charged for an entire day. The good things are the little bridge leading to the Fashion Valley Mall and the trolley station. The grounds are immaculate. Its close to the freeway, Old Town and Hillcrest. I suppose I would come here again for a conference but I would not choose this hotel for my own personal vacation. Its interesting that there is a generic "management response" for the more glowing reviews but none for any criticisms. Hmmmmm?

Reviews.Title: “Superlative experience.”
Reviews.Author: pizano3
Reviews.Content: Clean rooms, very reasonable rates, beautiful outdoor settings. Conveniently located for easy access to all of San Diego's tourist & shopping venues. Management is always courteous and very professional. I travel to San Diego every year and always stay at the Town and Country.

Reviews.Title: “potential to be better”
Reviews.Author: fabriciocoloccini
Reviews.Content: it's like riding in a 2008 BMW with a trashed-up interior. landscaping and outdoor quality is one of the best i've seen, but the rooms are crap. i changed rooms twice, and they're all 2 star quality. the bellhops and restaurant workers are great with customer service, although they dont seem to be treated well by superiors. waitor at tresilles was yelled at by supervisor in front of whole restaurant for something my sister screwed up on. bellhops didn't seem too happy with their superiors, but were great with us. when i asked for further accomodations, managing staff didn't seem like they were too enthused to help us. not much else to say. better rooms + better management + town & country = great san diego hotel. -Fabricio Coloccini Argentina

Reviews.Title: “Not *that* bad, and definintely unique”
Reviews.Author: KDUB7
Reviews.Content: Stayed at the T&C for a conference (does anyone stay there for any other reason?) I thought it was OK - yeah, the decor is about 20+ years out of date, but my room was clean, quiet, and safe. I awoke each morning to the sounds of birds. Loved the gardens, and liked being able to walk back to my room in between sessions. The layout is confusing at first, though: take your map with you! Location is very convenient - with the trolley stop just across the street, one doesn't even need a car.

Reviews.Title: “A time warp into the 50's & 60's”
Reviews.Author: vicPlano_TX
Reviews.Content: All of these reviews need some perspective. We were there for a small convention for four nights. This is not your usual hotel. It's a mish-mash of one and two floor outside entry motel rooms with a couple of dated hotel towers, with a multi-stage-built convention center. Most of those making reviews here aren't old enough to remember the motels of the 50's and 60's. This place has managed to keep those places alive in one place. Except they charged $12/day to park in rather under-sized spaces. Finding your way around was extremely frustrating since the map wasn't to scale and none of the "lanes" were marked, and the room numbers weren't on the buildings, just the doors. The upkeep was very good in general and the rooms were clean. But they are just stuffed full of beds, gaudy drapes, and valences and tv cabinet clutter. The closet was a hint of one. To get to the front wall a/c, it meant either squeezing between the bed and the front wall or plopping onto the bed next to that wall. Luckily, it didn't get very warm because that a/c was pretty weak. The bathroom area was amusing. That is, if you could chuckle at the toilet paper roll almost in your lap as you sat there. Large people might put holes in the wall with their elbows. That's because the walls were like thick paper. I could hear the guy in the next room coughing and the lady in the room above also coughing and making other "noises" in the bathroom. Kind of funny at times. You could almost name those by the sound. Yes, they charged $9.95 for wireless internet, that wasn't very high speed. Not a bad place by any means, the staff was very attentive and friendly. Would I stay there again? Only if the Residence Inn on the other side of the freeway was sold out.

Reviews.Title: “Convention by day, Old Town by night via Trolley”
Reviews.Author: thai2007
Reviews.Content: I'll agree with the other positive reviews posted by other conference attendees, but my main remark that does not appear to be addressed in this forum is the ease with which you can get in and out of the property after a day's conferences to enjoy San Diego, even without a car. The Trolley couldn't be easier to use, the clean, well lit station (with automated ticketing) located immediately behind the property, on the pedestrian path to the Fashion Valley mall. We never waited more than 10 minutes, and ran directly into Old Town Station well into the evening, with a transfer to the downtown line, all for a $5 day pass. Much better than most other convention-style resorts that do everything in their power to keep you on property, it was refreshing to be able to explore with the convenience of the Trolley at the end of a long day of seminars.

Reviews.Title: “Adding Insult to A Bad Experience”
Reviews.Author: Kinseysmom
Reviews.Content: We relocated from a lower priced property in order to receive upgraded facilities and services. The place was upscale and attractive but we didn't get our money's worth. In exchange for doubling our cost we did NOT receive a free newspaper, complimentary breakfast, free computer with high speed internet or bottled water, all of which were available at the lower priced property. There was ½ roll of toilet paper and no spare roll. We asked for a no-smoking room and found ashtrays in the room. The room was clean, there were plenty of towels. Restaurants were good but kept bankers' hours. Shuttles were available intermittently. Bell staff was overworked and understaffed. A welcome letter offered concierge services and discounts to local attractions but we received no help and there were no promised discounts. We wrote a letter to management with a form letter reply blaming the service staff and suggesting we try them again at a future stay in San Diego. I don't think so.

Reviews.Title: “Another Positive Experience!”
Reviews.Author: btboop
Reviews.Content: I wholeheartedly agree with the positive experiences reported on by the recent reviewer from southern Minnesota! I have just returned home from having attended a conference at the Town and Country from February 13-16, 2008. I too had read many less than favourable reviews about the resort, and so was not quite sure what to expect. However, my companions and I were more than pleasantly surprised by the facilities, service, and staff at the resort, and I was resolved to write my own positive review after returning home. We arrived at the resort shortly after noon on our day of arrival to find that our room was not yet ready (check-in isn't supposed to be until 3 PM, after all). The only room available was one without a view (the brick wall mentioned by other reviewers), and so we opted to wait for another. The front desk staff were most apologetic, and quickly called for the bell captain to store our luggage until later. As it happened, we did not have to wait until 3 PM for our room; our luggage was retrieved and we were transported by golf cart to the Royal Palm Tower. Derek then brought our luggage right up to our room for us, too! Our double room on the 9th floor was directly off the elevator lobby, but we were never disturbed by noise from the elevator, guests in adjoining rooms, or the freeway. We had a lovely view of the entire resort and the surrounding hills from our balcony, which was furnished with a white wrought iron table and chairs. Our room was quite spacious, and was furnished with dark colonial-style furniture. The 2 queen-sized beds were separated by a writing desk and chair, 2 armchairs flanked another round table, a long dressing bench sat under the picture of the little girl in the blue dress (very cute!), and an armoire housed the TV over three drawers for clothing. The dark blue carpet looked to be quite new, and the bedspreads matched the draperies and pleated valances over the beds. Our room also had a second sink and counter in the dressing area outside the bathroom - very handy when three women are sharing a room! The mirrored sliding doors on the closet were appreciated, as was the heatlamp on a timer in the bathroom. The weather on one day of our stay was cool and rainy - between 45 & 50 degrees - but the heat in our room worked very well to keep us absolutely comfortable. By the way, a photo posted by another reviewer is a bit misleading: of course all of the rooms in the Royal Palm Tower have windows! The photo is actually a shot of the open-air corridors along the BACK side of the tower from which the rooms are accessed. We were very impressed by the conference facilities at the Town and Country. In addition to the main exhibit hall and ballrooms, the resort has a multitude of break-out rooms of various sizes. Sumptuous carpets, mirrors, and crystal chandeliers adorn the foyers, and the restrooms feature marble countertops and tiled floors. The banks of smaller meeting rooms are separated by walkways bordered by well-kept flowerbeds and many benches and tables for further conversation. The only caution I would give regarding the facilities is that the sheer size of the resort requires quite a bit of walking back and forth from your accommodations to various conference facilities - a consideration for anyone with mobility issues. We also enjoyed our meals at the Town & Country Resort. The breakfast buffet at the Terrace Cafe does offer a good variety of hot and cold choices - certainly more than we could eat - and the regular menu for all meals has something for everyone. Our final dinner at Trellises Garden Grille was more expensive, but was delicious and beautifully presented. I can't say enough about the two banquets we enjoyed - one of roast beef and the other of chicken breasts stuffed with spinach! Beautifully cooked - beef still pink inside, vegetables crisp-tender, all piping hot, despite service for over 1000 attendees! Prompt service by unfailingly pleasant and accommodating wait staff. Oh, and the desserts! TOO decadent! We found that the Town & Country Resort was located quite centrally for all of our needs. It was only a 10-15 minute shuttle ride from the airport, and was a maximum 5-10 minute walk from the Fashion Valley trolley stop. It was quite easy to take the trolley system downtown to Seaport Village. And the Fashion Valley Mall begins just the other side of the transit centre/trolley stop. In summary, I would not hesitate to visit the Town & Country Resort again. The facility is quite charming and very clean, and the flowers and landscaping are beautiful. The staff were unfailingly pleasant and eager to assist whenever needed. My only regret is that our conference was not longer!

Reviews.Title: “A Positive Experience at the Town and Country!”
Reviews.Author: gjkov
Reviews.Content: After reading all the negative reviews, we were also more than a bit apprehensive about our stay at the Town and Country. But since that is where our conference was being held, we had little choice. So we went into it trying to have as positive an attitude as we could, and I am pleased to say we were delighted to have had a very different experience. It was almost as if we were staying at a different resort! Please bear with a rather long review, as we feel we’d like to share the positives. We are simple middle class people who do a fair amount of traveling, mostly staying in mid range accomodations (Marriott, Hilton Garden Inns and Hamptons, Holiday Inns and the like). From the moment we arrived, all the staff was never anything but pleasant and helpful. This included the front desk, cleaning and other support people, restaurant staff, concierge staff, conference center people, as well as several higher level managers we encountered and talked with one day. I can honestly say we never encountered a crabby staff person during the week. We were booked in the Royal Palm tower, and having read about some of the rooms with views of brick walls, we specifically requested a middle room with balcony overlooking the pool area when checking in. We were nicely accommodated with this request….as with the few others we made during our stay. When we got to our room we found we were close to the elevator…which we had read was a problem for another reviewer in regard to noise. But we were never disturbed by noise from the elevator or any of the rooms around us. We never even heard any noise from the rooms around us and we knew people were staying in them. There was staff with golf carts to help you bring your bags to your room, if needed. We had a rental car, so did not need that service, but we never had trouble finding a convenient parking spot, as some other reviewers spoke of. We could see that there were not as many parking spots by the garden bungalows, so maybe was not as easy to park there, but we never had any trouble in the big lot by the Royal Palm. And some spoke of roads within the resort that were hard to navigate, but we never had trouble with that. It is a rather big place, but not that big. It was a nice, couple minute walk from our building to the lobby area, which were on opposite ends of the resort. Our Royal Palm room was very spacious and nicely appointed; with a king bed, easy chair and ottoman, small table and chair as well as a writing desk. There was also the armoire with TV, bed tables and both floor and table lamps in various locations around the room that provided good lighting. The balcony had 2 comfortable padded chairs and a small table and we enjoyed time out there every day. The bathroom was spacious and had an outer area with a counter and sink, as well as the sink in the actual bathroom. I will agree that the shower head was mounted very low, but if that was the worst thing wrong, we certainly could easily deal with it. There was a large closet, too, with plenty of hangers. And though the comforter was not of a design I would choose for my bed at home (as with most hotels), it was certainly not objectionable. And besides being comfortable, the room was very clean and cleaned nicely each day throughout our stay. I read a number of reviews that mentioned the proximity of the freeway. And while it did run close to the front of the resort and we could see the traffic from our balcony, we could barely hear any noise with it. Even in early morning when the resort was very quiet, so it never disturbed us in the least. Was it very scenic? Not really and certainly not like looking at the ocean, but those rooms on the coast have much heftier price tags attached, too. And since the layout of the resort was so nice; with trees, lovely gardens and flowers, pools, etc, it was not hard to overlook the freeway. The grounds were also kept very clean. There were always cleaning crews out first thing in the morning cleaning the pool and other common areas. And besides doing a great job, they were also quick to return a smile and a greeting. The pools and whirlpool looked very clean and though we did not use them, heard many good things from folks in our conference who did. There was some construction going on, as they were renovating some areas, but it was very easy to get around and did not disturb us in any way. Food at the resort was a little on the expensive side, but no more so than in other restaurants we ate in around San Diego. And all the food we had was very well prepared, portions more than adequate and wait staff very pleasant. The breakfast buffet was especially nice, with good hot food and many choices; scrambled eggs, potatoes, bacon, sausage, pancakes, french toast, beautiful fresh fruit, cereals and a multitude of bread and pastry choices. Some thought it was a little expensive at $14.50, but included all beverages, so really was not much more than breakfast with juice and coffee at someplace like Perkins and was all you could eat. The Terrace also had nice salads, sandwiches and great homemade soups along with some other entrees and a fresh fish choice each day, making it a good choice for any meal of the day. The Trellis is a little more upscale and rather expensive for dinner (we thought), but we had a very nice lunch there. Kelly’s Steakhouse has nice dinner offerings in midrange pricing. We never ate at Charlie’s but heard from others it was also quite good. You can also easily walk over to the mall, which has a variety of restaurants in all price ranges. The convention center was large, but once you got the lay of the land, it was not hard to navigate. The convention staff was also very nice and the meals we were provided during our conference were excellent! All in all we had a very good experience with the Town and Country and loved our stay in San Diego.

Reviews.Title: “A rebuttal of the great staff I experienced”
Reviews.Author: JimmyR
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the Town and Country for 8 days in the last week of January, 2008 while at a week long convention. I was somewhat worried about the booking due to the recent negative comments on this site and thought I should provide my input. Due to flight issues I arrived at 2:30 AM and went to room 1928....I opened the curtains and I was staring at the infamous concrete wall with no view other than brick work. I called down to the front desk and asked to be placed on a list to change rooms as this room was not acceptable. I was met with a friendly voice and told she would place me on the list and I could change in the morning. I went to the front desk around 11:00 and was guaranteed I would get a different room but they needed to wait for an update as to what rooms had been vacated and cleaned. I went back at 2:30 and was placed in 1132, an excellent ground floor room that actually walked out to a large patio that I used everyday. I used room service on three occasions and found the food to be of good quality and reasonably priced. And a large pizza is really large....and will feed 4 people easily. A co-worker requested a room change later in the week as her spouse was arriving with their 18 month old......this was handled with ease and they were allocated a room close by to us so that they could sit outside at night and use their baby monitor to llisten to their child. All in all, I would return to this hotel for the location and accomodating staff.

Reviews.Title: “Poor Customer Service”
Reviews.Author: bethly
Reviews.Content: Our team booked this hotel because it was recommended by the KROC Center. When I walked in the front desk to check in the rep was really cold as if they are doing us a favor. Then, the night we checked in I called room service to place an order for the next morning and I was told that they can not deliver our food until 7:45 a.m. because they already have a lot of orders. I mentioned their hours of operation from 6:00 a.m. to 11:00 a.m. and the order taker just laughed it off and didn't care. I then called the front office and I was transfered to the manager and before I can say anything the manager said he can not help me and I have to talk to the restaurant manager. I said I was tired of waiting (on hold for 10 minutes) and didn't want to be transfered. I was really getting frustrated, the manager response was "OK have a good night" and hanged up. The same night I requested a wake up call for 5:30 a.m. so that we can have breakfast in one of the restaurant in the hotel, since they can not accomodate us with room service, unfortunately, I never got my wake-up call. I called the front desk and said I didn't get my wake up call and the receptionist response was "I don't know I just got here". I was so disappointed in this hotel. Never again shall I stay at the Town and Country Resort. The hotel is old and outdated, it probably would have been tolerable if the customer service was excellent to compensate for the lack of ammenities.

Reviews.Title: “Would not stay here again; very mediocre hotel and cold front office”
Reviews.Author: experiencedtrvlr32
Reviews.Content: My office booked the hotel for the night before I actually was to be there. Front office was cold and didn't seem to care when I checked in and when I asked if they could please consider not charging me for the extra night. They said I was a no show and that was their policy. I was there for a professional meeting and had stayed there several times before but they indicated this was their policy with no exceptions. The fitness facility is extremely outdated and yet it charges $8.00 for use even if one isn't using the spa. The bicycles stick and one can't even listen to one's own music since the bikes are so old. There are no elliptical machines. When I complained, the spa desk just smiled and gave me a comments card. The hotel room had no facial tissue and no shower cap. The walls are not well insulated so noise from the room above (even though I was in the renovated section) are very audible.

Reviews.Title: “Conveniently Located…But Then, So Is Hell”
Reviews.Author: Yobabs
Reviews.Content: Our family converged on San Diego for a small reunion from December 27-30, 2007. My brother, a San Diego resident, made reservations for us at the Town & Country, via Expedia, months ahead of time. He also used Expedia to pay, and to request 4 double queen rooms. At check-in, we were given four double queen rooms, but told that we would have to move to different rooms after the first night. No explanation was given at the time, but we were told by Javier, the night manager, that the new rooms would be an upgrade, that they would be double queens, and that he would comp our three days’ parking (parking is a hefty $14/day) and two days’ breakfasts. Now, when I arrive at a hotel, I really want to unpack and settle in - and I don’t want to worry about packing again until it’s time to leave. I absolutely detest the unsettled feeling of staying one night here and one night there, even if it’s different rooms in the same hotel. So Javier’s news that we would be moving after the first night was anything but welcome. The comps were something, as was his assurance that we’d be getting better rooms, but bottom line, they weren’t worth the hassle we were looking at in changing rooms. The property is huge and sprawling. It’s like a small community, albeit a community that never understood the point of a planning commission. There’s a bit of parking here, a bit there, and even a parking structure – but we didn’t see an actual entrance to that, so it didn’t do us any good. We drove to the building where our four rooms were located, and circled the surrounding area a couple of times looking for parking, but there was none within the same Zip code as the rooms; we ended up parking just this side of Tijuana. To add to our delight, the rooms were on the second floor of a somewhat ratty old building, with no elevator, so once we humped our bags from the car to the building, we hauled them up an outdoor concrete staircase. It was starting to dawn on us that this was not so much a hotel, as a motel with pretensions. The rooms were small, a bit shabby, and one had a funny smell that gave my daughter a headache within seconds of entering, but they were non-smoking double queen rooms, and all four of our rooms were in the same small cell-block, er, building. The room design was a bit odd; I didn’t even find the closet for several hours. (Note: in my defense, I didn’t actually spend those hours searching for a closet. When I didn’t spot one right off the bat, I just assumed there wasn’t one, and was therefore surprised to discover one later, sort of tucked behind the sink.) There was no point in unpacking, but there was not sufficient space to accommodate an open suitcase, as we were being thrown out the next morning anyway. We finally cleared the hotel’s junk from the wooden table to put an open suitcase on it. I awoke early the next morning, increasingly frustrated at how we were being treated. In particular, it kept going through my mind that the only reason for moving us from our block of four rooms was that the hotel was more interested in accommodating the new guests than in making our group happy. At around 6, I got dressed and ventured to the lobby to see if they could do any better for us. I spoke with Christina at the desk. On a map, she showed me where our new rooms would be, circling an area encompassing multiple buildings, while she tried to sound like the rooms were somehow close together. She, too, assured me that we would have double queen rooms. I mentioned the lack of convenient parking, and she pointed out a number of parking lots around the periphery of the property. Perhaps there were parking spaces in those far-flung lots; perhaps there are parking spaces on the moon, too, but they wouldn’t do us much good, being nowhere near our rooms. Anyway, Christina said that they would make the move as hassle-free as they could, and we at least wouldn’t have to wait through the check-in line again. After packing what little we’d bothered to unpack, we had breakfast at the buffet at the Terraces. It was a typical breakfast buffet, with scrambled eggs, bacon, sausage, pancakes, etc. Nothing special (e.g., no omelet bar), but it was OK. A couple of notes to remember: if you like to enjoy a beverage with your meal, order it before you visit the buffet; otherwise, it will arrive about the time you leave. Also, the nearest restrooms are located in the convention center (i.e., nowhere in the Terraces building), so plan accordingly. We checked out of our rooms (we had to go to the desk for this: for some reason, they couldn’t just transfer the account information without seeing our by-now snarling faces), and we checked our bags with the bell desk. After spending the day out, we came back to check in to the new rooms. Not only did they need to see our faces, but they needed to see our ID’s in order to do this, so we had to have one representative from each room turn up, with ID, at the desk. No idea why. The funny thing was, they enforced this ID thing with some of our rooms, but not all. They did have our keys all ready, and we trooped off to the new four rooms, which were located, respectively, here, over there, way over there, and way the hell over there. Thanks ever so much for the effort, Christina. The new rooms were, indeed, nicer. They were on the ground floor and were larger. However, each had a just one king-size bed, despite the assurances of both Javier-the-night-manager and Christina-the-morning-desk-person that we’d have double queens. So as soon as we looked at the first room, we called the front desk to see what was up. This time, the story was different. The person on the line said that she had no idea why Javier and Christina had both promised double queen rooms; according to her, both Javier and Christina should have known, at the time they were making their promises, that no such rooms would be available to us. Now, if we wanted to move again the next day (call the Guinness Book of Records – three rooms in three days!), they could accommodate us. The bottom line was, we now had four rooms, each with a king bed in it, and, as the hotel had nothing more appropriate to offer us, we requested rollaways to be brought in ASAP. As it transpired, the term “ASAP” didn’t mean much to the staff – they brought them at such a leisurely pace that we left for dinner not knowing whether there would be adequate bedding when we got back that night. In fact, one granddaughter ended up in tears, as Grandma had to cancel a planned sleepover because she didn’t know whether there would be another bed in her room. By then, I was really getting mad. I told the person on the phone that they should be looking at comping rooms at this point. She said they couldn’t, as the reservations were made via Expedia – and that our requests for double queens were only requests, and did not have to be honored, since they, too, had been made via Expedia. My pointing out that two hotel employees, one of them a manager, had promised double queens, didn’t make a dent. (Note to self: Self, in future, never book a hotel via Expedia; maybe use it to search, but book via the hotel directly.) The new rooms were pretty, but noisy. Each had a nice big bay window, which, I think, was the reason why anyone walking by, conversing in normal tones, sounded like they were right in our room, conversing via megaphones. Also, the shower head was mounted so low that, even though I’m only 5’5”, I had to kneel to wash my hair. (And no, it wasn’t like that in order to accommodate folks with disabilities – if that were the reason, there would have been handrails. It was just mounted at a stupid height.) Now, to be fair, I must say that they did supply some of those little extras that really make a trip memorable. For instance, one of our four rooms came complete with a dirty diaper; it was on top of the armoire, along with the rest of the trash left by the previous occupants. And another room had a little touch of the beach in it: sand all over the tub. Given that a rinse was all it took to clean out the sand, it was clear that the maids had not bothered to rinse the tub, let alone properly clean it, even between guests. Glad I opted for a shower. The bottom line here is that the Town & Country is woefully mismanaged, and staffed by folks who will look you in the eye, smile, and lie their guts out. The cleaning crew couldn’t get a job mucking out a pig sty. There are thousands and thousands of hotel rooms on Hotel Circle in San Diego; if the only vacancies are at the Town & Country…well, try another city. San Francisco’s nice.

Reviews.Title: “Quaint and luxurious”
Reviews.Author: SF_egret
Reviews.Content: This is a fun place--a sprawling property with lovely gardens, multiple restaurants, little cottage-style rooms around courtyards and a few tower blocks of hotel rooms. There are palm trees, gazebos, rose bushes everywhere, and something like 4 picturesque swimming pools. There is a really fancy spa with a nice fitness center too. Right behind the hotel is part of the San Diego River, and a bridge over that river takes one to a posh shopping center (Fashion Valley). My room was a sweet little cottage room with cherry wood colonial style furniture and a dark blue carpet. There was a huge four-poster bed, nice little writing desk, and a table by the bay window with two lovely big chairs. It opened directly out into a little courtyard with palm trees, a gazebo, lawn and rosebushes. It was a beautiful room, and a lovely, peaceful place to stay. I enjoyed walking around the grounds at night and in the morning--it was very well maintained. Weird stuff: Two of the more casual restaurants were shut when I was staying there, and the one that was open was too fancy for a person in casual clothes so I had to order (pricey) room service instead. Also, you have to pay for every little extra you would expect for free from other hotels, such as in-room internet service, parking in front of your own room (!?) and use of the fitness center. The fitness center is really a good one, but yeesh, uses is usually free at most other places. Good perks: On the south side of the river a block or two east of the hotel, you can get onto a very beautiful running path that goes for miles along the San Diego River. It's like a dream it is so pretty in the morning and you would never even believe you were running near a major highway and a lot of upscale shopping centers. Part of it goes past posh condos, but some of it is a little more isolated. It is paved and at one point there is also a path along the northside of the river. It was spectacular. You can also access the trolley from near the hotel, which is pretty cool.

Reviews.Title: “Better Places for the Price”
Reviews.Author: Cut2TheChase
Reviews.Content: I go to San Diego on Business Trips quite often. This was my first stay at Town and Country which advertises itself as a "Resort" Hotel. Checking in and Out, I found the folks at the front desk were in too much of a Hurry (Not because there were others waiting). The Entryways and road markings need to be better defined. Example: I had to leave the Check-in area and drive all the way around to the otherside where the Tower is. The girl at the desk rushed to drag a pen across the map to tell me where my room was and how to get there. What she didn't tell me was that I didn't have to use the Road in front of the Convention Center (Which I wasn't aware that was part of the Hotel) but instead, I could turn right up what looks like a brick walkway but is actually a road that takes you up and through right past the curbside of the convention center to the back parking area (Which also isn't clearly marked as Town and Country but says Convention Center). I had to drive back to the front and ask one of the Valets there for better directions and he helped me 100 times better than the "In-a-hurry" girl at the front desk. The place is a maze and needs a vast improvement in regards to markings and directions. OK..Parking..$6.00 per day..Why? Should be included but not. My room had a view of tiny road and workers washing their cars in the morning. I've had better rooms at a skanky Motel 6. This was not worth $120.00 (Yes I had a discount through Business). Good things..Kelly's Steak House..The Fillet Minon literally melts in your Mouth and the Service was great. High Priced but worth it. Since my company was having a Christmas party there, it wasn't until the actual day of the party that we found out where it was to be held. The Catering folks and Phone at Town and Country were great. They could have made a few runs to ask if anyone wanted water (One kind of gets thirsty after dancing some). Not that it was a big issue as we finally hunted one of them down and got some more water.
